subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{liushu|p}} – a person ({{zh-l|*大}}) with a tattooed face, depicting penal tattooing ({{zh-l|*墨}}), one of the {{w|Five Punishments|five punishments}} of ancient China. In the bronze inscriptions from the {{w|Spring and Autumn}} and {{w|Warring States}} periods, dots were sometimes added around {{zh-l|*大}}, leading ''{{w|Shuowen}}'' to erroneously interpret the character as an {{Han compound|𡆧|炎|ls=ic|t1=chimney|t2=fire; flame|nocap=1}} — fire burning under a chimney, causing it to become black from the smoke.

subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
From {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*s-maŋ ~ s-mak}}. Cognate with {{och-l|墨|ink}}.

The sense of “hack” is a {{psm|zh|en|hack|nocap=1}}.
